response_text: I would say the most significant think I would say I learnt from this course is the method of applying economic theory and different models to real-life, practical markets. course: ECON-325S-01 : ECON ANALYSIS OF ENERGY ISSUES.ECON-325S-01.ENERGY-325S-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about a sector that was completely new to me, the energy industry, and it opened my eyes to a completely different way of thinking. Specifically, I learned about natural gas markets, oil monopolies, coal, and renewable energy sources. Thinking about these from an engineering and economic perspective also benefitted me, as I never considered phenomena such as the resource trap, hedging, and futures markets. It was also cool to learn about the history of these markets and how they developed and changed alongside different regulations and policies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I would say the most significant think I would say I learnt from this course is the method of applying economic theory and different models to real-life, practical markets. In core econ classes, we see how supply and demand and competitive equilibrium work, but I enjoyed applying those frameworks to coal production models and OPEC and thinking about how to world actually operates. I also would say my presentation skills improved through our final presentation. Finally, I did definitely learn a lot about the grid and the electricity system in the United States.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about a sector that was completely new to me, the energy industry, and it opened my eyes to a completely different way of thinking. Specifically, I learned about natural gas markets, oil monopolies, coal, and renewable energy sources. Thinking about these from an engineering and economic perspective also benefitted me, as I never considered phenomena such as the resource trap, hedging, and futures markets. It was also cool to learn about the history of these markets and how they developed and changed alongside different regulations and policies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained a comprehensive understanding of how ESG considerations are integrated into financial markets, including the mechanisms behind ESG-themed funds, sustainable investing trends, and the impact of ESG factors on investment decision-making. I learned about the various ESG reporting frameworks and third-party analytics tools, such as Bloomberg, MSCI, Sustainalytics, and S&P Global. Lastly, the course highlighted the evolving role of ESG in financial markets, including the challenges and opportunities of navigating regulatory changes, addressing greenwashing, and incorporating climate risk into investment strategies.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: After the first class, prompted by others in the class, I went up to Prof Wedding (Chris) and asked him what I should do about my pending job deadline/decision. I made a pros and cons list following his advice, and this helped orient my thinking / make more peace with the choice I was mostly likely going to make anyway. The rest of the classes and content flowed well following this, as it was helpful to hear about others' career progressions and interests – no path is ever linear, and choosing one thing does not set you down one forever. I really liked that the class pushed me out of my comfort zone, as Chris is engaging as a speaker and attentive as a professor (encouraging those to speak up, giving constructive feedback on slide decks, etc.). He organizes the 2.5 hour classes as a combination of lectures, activities, discussions, and speakers, leaving you no space to feel lost or bored (or if so, easily recoverable).

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Chris is great.  Really strong practitioner and experience, very engaging lectures and class discussions.  But, Chris is clear that he doesn't care about grades versus what you learn.  So if you care about your marks (or simply take pride in your work and engagement), consider who the TA(s) are during Drop/Add and how well you trust their feedback as actually being representative. Know that it is very possible to both get really strong/positive feedback from Chris on an assignment or presentation that is worth 20% of your grade, and then receive one of the lowest grades in the class for the very same assignment.

response_text: The instructor is a great guy and clearly passionate about Climate Tech, but so many things about this course were so bad. Oh and the students were not able to reach out to the professor. I directly emailed him multiple times and never got a response back. Students are forced to communicate directly with the TAs and have them be messengers to the professor. If I could I would restructure the course from the group up or not even teach it if the the changes are not made.

response_text: In this course, I gained a practical understanding of the full lifecycle of non-residential solar PV project development. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course helped me develop insights and ways of thinking that will continue to impact how I approach environmental management for the rest of my career (as well as my life beyond work as a consumer of energy resources!). First, Professor Johnson's lectures introduced us to fundamental topics in energy technology at a pretty remarkable combination of breadth and depth. Working backwards from electricity transmission to generation, Professor Johnson zeroed in on the technologies that will most animate our work while putting them in context of our energy infrastructure system. The assignments challenged me to apply my communication and quantitative skills to new types of questions. But I feel like my most important takeaway from this class will be an ability to unpack energy narratives and think critically about the choices and assumptions that undergird these narratives.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Johnson is incredibly passionate about teaching. He is committed to making course information accessible to different types of learners - via assignments with a mixture of quantitative and qualitative questions that target different ways of thinking about energy technology, and course materials available in different formats (notes, presentation slides, lectures). Throughout the course, I was very grateful for his willingness to name the challenges of working on energy systems in such politically/economically/culturally tumultuous contexts (especially during a "current events" segment of each class) while remaining committed to developing our foundational understanding of energy technologies - he maintained this balance with grace and with care.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This course felt like it annotated version of what we read in the news about energy - perhaps because Professor Johnson started each class with a segment on current events in energy, but mostly because it taught us to think critically about claims that companies, government officials, nonprofits, media, etc. make about the roles that different technologies play now or may play in a future energy landscape. This conversation between energy narratives we hear outside of class and the technologies as we unpacked them during class made this course feel incredibly intellectually stimulating. The assignments and exams felt like they provided a perfect degree of challenge - I was pushed to apply class concepts in novel ways, but with the confidence of working from the solid foundation that Professor Johnson built during the lectures.

response_text:

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The exams are insanely hard and force me to learn the material really well. The exam format being short answers and multiple choice (literally choose more than one thing) forces me to understand the material instead of basing things on pure guesses if it is multiple choice (single choice). I don't think Dr. Pratson is a terrible lecturer, but he is not a very kind person. After the first exam he basically shamed the entire class for doing poorly by comparing us to the mechanical engineer Duke undergrads. He also straight up told us he doesn't like to hand out good grades and there would not be practice exams or redos later in the semester. It's almost like he does not want us to succeed in this course. I got very high scores on both the exams so far so I don't have too big of an issue with how he teaches, but I don't like his attitude when he addresses his students.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to put certain business tools into practice. I learned how to research and develop a market size using incomplete information. I learned how how VCs work and the type of information they are looking for in a presentation. I also changed how I look at green energy projects and realized they are much more complex than just harnessing a renewable energy source.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I was able to think more critically about business models and to assess the effectiveness for climate and impact-focused businesses in particular for creating the impact they desire while still remaining profitable and able to stay in business. I also learned the challenges of working with a first time founder, and trying to open them up to different ways of thinking, as they can get very bogged down in the details of their organization and double down on current methods of doing things, which might not be the most time or other resource efficient. Lastly, in working with a team and taking on the unofficial role of the project manager, I learned more about how to motivate team members, and where I need to provide a little push where needed vs. when to step back and let other people do the work on their own terms, even if I might do it a bit differently myself.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: There was a lot of open debate/conversation. Ideas and assumptions were constantly challenged and most everyone was participating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think that the "lessons" that Michelle and Alexis gave were very high level overviews of some basic concepts taught in business school, but did not go into anywhere near enough detail to be helpful. I think that some more activities around applying these concepts, or more detailed lessons could have been helpful. Alternatively, perhaps a short reading could be provided prior to lessons so that the class could all get to at least a baseline understanding prior to the class discussions. This could be more helpful for people who were less familiar, and could then allow for a richer discussion for people who were already familiar and wanted to try to take their learning and application to the next level.As noted above, I also think it would have been more interesting and helpful to meet the founders at the beginning of the course as well, and give us more context and more to think about/ consider throughout the term, reducing the time of the learning curve, and allowing for more time for critical thinking and analysis.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: More in class exercises would be helpful. For example, we could be doing case studies in assessing companies on their markets, or we could gain practice building TAM SAM SOM by doing it multiple times for multiple companies, instead of just once. Sometimes in a team, only one person does it while the others do other aspects of the project, so some of us miss out on some skills which other get.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it if you're willing to be invested in client work, and in making weekly presentations as opposed to other forms of coursework. Course content is useful if you want to dive deeper into certain markets, but the course leaves you to do a lot of research on your own, you will not necessarily get insights about the climate tech market from the instructors, you will get guidance on how to explore those markets.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course utilized homework, handouts, lecture, quizzes, and labs to teach us. The homework was the most instructive of all and where I learned the most. The homework was challenging and often required many hours with TA assistance to complete.  Quizzes worked well and should be kept as a measure of attendance and engagement. I can't recommend much beyond that as I found interpretations of this course varied dramatically depending on the student.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

response_text: The instructor took an extremely diverse cohort of students with varying backgrounds in math, science, economics, and statistics and taught us the basic basics of modelling energy generation, LCOE, python, and probabilistic models - I think that there's a great deal of effort in creating a course that builds each week upon knowledge taught in the previous weeks, and I'm planning on keeping every single excel spreadsheet and powerpoint in a file to refer back to for future reference.  This course was very difficult for me (liberal arts major) but I felt like I was successful because it's been carefully crafted to step us all along the way.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciated that the classes were recorded in Panopto because I relied on that resource to go back and review the content while I completed the homework assignments. The TA sessions were also vital for me to get help with the assignments which I could not have completed by simply attending the lectures. I found the course challenging to keep up with from day one and I am grateful that Dalia was willing to help me find extra help and solutions throughout the semester. The TA Jaimie Wargo was amazing and I want to give her extra kudos for everything she did this semester. I specifically want to highlight that she reserved a classroom with a whiteboard for her meetings which helped students visualize segments of the homework problems. I wish the other TAs had also reserved classrooms. Jaimie also added select 1-1 office hours that I found helpful. I wish there were more TAs and tutors available to work one-on-one with students who were struggling in class because I know there were many of us.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is very much a "take what you want from it" course. Easy to pass, but not easy to get As on everything. Be prepared to sit through a lot of discussion-styled back-and-forth conversation instead of getting a lecture. If you prefer an organized lecture-based course with short answer assignments and clear-cut assessments, this is not the class for you. The professor is not for you, and you should consider how many other required courses and electives you have to take for the BE concentration. Maybe consider switching to EEP or EAM so you have fewer required courses that are not up your alley.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how early civilizations first harnessed energy, how the industrial revolution shifted us from wood to coal power which enabled many new technologies like the steam engine, and about more modern energy utilization like oil, electricity, and nuclear. I also learned how to analyze historical documents and interpret them in context. Additionally, I got better at managing time and workload.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Firstly, this course helped me improve at reading and analyzing primary documents. It also helped me engage in meaningful discussions in class with my peers, which I think will be very useful for the next four years. Lastly, this course developed my thinking in a way to consider questions in the contexts of many different areas and times. We often talked about technological frameworks and this led me to grasp with the idea that the way we understand energy today is not nearly the way people would have understood energy centuries ago.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

2. I analyzed solar energy in my final research project and considered possible alternatives for solar cell materials.
3. I learned how to effectively take notes on primary sources and use past behaviors in the energy market to predict future behaviors.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course was highly informative. I enjoyed learning about the development of energy systems and transitions over the past thousands of years. I learned numerous things, including the transition from nomadic settlements to agriculturalist and pastoralist societies. I enjoyed learning about coal transitions in the Industrial Revolution and how energy sources affected lifestyles, including how the development of the steam engine related to time-space compression. I also enjoyed learning about France's centralized approach to nuclear energy construction in the late 1900s. I also developed numerous skills in this class, such as gaining presentational experience through leading class discussions and giving presentations on self-selected topics. I enjoyed collaborating with classmates and also creating debriefs on different subjects.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the history of energy systems and how energy transitions occurred. This includes the interdisciplinary nature of the study of energy, which includes political, economic, technological, and historical factors. I also learned how energy systems impacted state-building and the rise of civilizations from both ancient and present times.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I developed skills in
1. Reading historical documents (both primary sources and secondary sources)
2. Note-taking
3. Synthesizing prior research into a new study

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a ton in this course. We learned how to analyze historical texts and compare patterns in the development of energy systems to apply them to a modern context. I've learned about early human settlements and the tools they used to improve their own living conditions. I've learned about the early industrial revolution and how humans used charcoal and later coal to drive steam engines. I've learned about oil and gas and the nuclear energy systems' development as well, which remarkably followed a similar pattern to that of coal. An example of these similar patterns is how there was initial adoption in an area that allowed fuel sources to maintain themselves (coal being used to mine more coal, oil being used on trains that carried oil for example).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the history of energy as it developed in tandem with humanity, changing the species as much as the species changed it. I also found a wealth of knowledge in our readings about nuclear and new energy forms, an area that I would be very interested in furthering my knowledge of in future courses. I also really developed a vocabulary for talking about energy, one that expressed itself in key terms that we would structure our classes around and that I feel cover a wide stretch of multidisciplinary phenomena, as applied to energy.

response_text: Coming into the course, be aware that it will not just be an overview of renewable energy and that class will be more technical and math-based than a humanities-based environmental science class. However, it is a really good class if you're interested in learning the science, physics, and math behind energy generation and different forms of energy. All in all, I think the class had great potential but just needed more interaction. Lastly, the class itself is not super hard, but it's important to pay close attention to lectures for the test.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course helped me develop insights and ways of thinking that will continue to impact how I approach environmental management for the rest of my career (as well as my life beyond work as a consumer of energy resources!). First, Professor Johnson's lectures introduced us to fundamental topics in energy technology at a pretty remarkable combination of breadth and depth. Working backwards from electricity transmission to generation, Professor Johnson zeroed in on the technologies that will most animate our work while putting them in context of our energy infrastructure system. The assignments challenged me to apply my communication and quantitative skills to new types of questions. But I feel like my most important takeaway from this class will be an ability to unpack energy narratives and think critically about the choices and assumptions that undergird these narratives.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Johnson is incredibly passionate about teaching. He is committed to making course information accessible to different types of learners - via assignments with a mixture of quantitative and qualitative questions that target different ways of thinking about energy technology, and course materials available in different formats (notes, presentation slides, lectures). Throughout the course, I was very grateful for his willingness to name the challenges of working on energy systems in such politically/economically/culturally tumultuous contexts (especially during a "current events" segment of each class) while remaining committed to developing our foundational understanding of energy technologies - he maintained this balance with grace and with care.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This course felt like it annotated version of what we read in the news about energy - perhaps because Professor Johnson started each class with a segment on current events in energy, but mostly because it taught us to think critically about claims that companies, government officials, nonprofits, media, etc. make about the roles that different technologies play now or may play in a future energy landscape. This conversation between energy narratives we hear outside of class and the technologies as we unpacked them during class made this course feel incredibly intellectually stimulating. The assignments and exams felt like they provided a perfect degree of challenge - I was pushed to apply class concepts in novel ways, but with the confidence of working from the solid foundation that Professor Johnson built during the lectures.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I personally loved how the class was extremely structured. The organization of the topics and the economic concepts behind them was clear, and the professor presented these topics succinctly. I grew to really enjoy that we were provided the PowerPoint slides for the class as a .ppt, rather than a .pdf, as this allowed me to edit and modify the slides for my own personal review and understanding. The presentation style was warm, inviting, and drew me in to learning the content.I must add that this has been one of the most enjoyable classes I have taken, despite frustrations with some elements described within this review. Dr. Bennear is a fantastic lecturer and is very welcoming and illuminating.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. LCA requires a ton of assumptions and best estimations due to inaccurate, insufficient, or unknown data. Look at results with a grain of salt.
2. I learned how to use Ecoinvent, Sustainable Minds, and Excel to calculate LCAs. I now understand all of the different environmental impacts that go into an LCA.
3. You can choose different boundaries for your LCA based on your goals and audience, eg. cradle-to-grave or cradle-to-gate.

response_text: The exams are insanely hard and force me to learn the material really well. The exam format being short answers and multiple choice (literally choose more than one thing) forces me to understand the material instead of basing things on pure guesses if it is multiple choice (single choice). I don't think Dr. Pratson is a terrible lecturer, but he is not a very kind person. After the first exam he basically shamed the entire class for doing poorly by comparing us to the mechanical engineer Duke undergrads. He also straight up told us he doesn't like to hand out good grades and there would not be practice exams or redos later in the semester. It's almost like he does not want us to succeed in this course. I got very high scores on both the exams so far so I don't have too big of an issue with how he teaches, but I don't like his attitude when he addresses his students.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciated that the classes were recorded in Panopto because I relied on that resource to go back and review the content while I completed the homework assignments. I specifically want to highlight that she reserved a classroom with a whiteboard for her meetings which helped students visualize segments of the homework problems. I wish the other TAs had also reserved classrooms. Jaimie also added select 1-1 office hours that I found helpful. I wish there were more TAs and tutors available to work one-on-one with students who were struggling in class because I know there were many of us.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Energy modeling is probably one of the hardest courses you will take because the content is taught at a fast pace and the assignments will push you to apply the knowledge you recently learned. Be sure to plan ahead since the assignments are weekly and they will take a good amount of time to complete. Definitely go to office hours because the TAs are very helpful and will be able to guide you in the right direction. However, you will be rewarded with the new skills that you learn that are very applicable to just about anything you could do after graduating.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is very much a "take what you want from it" course. Easy to pass, but not easy to get As on everything. Be prepared to sit through a lot of discussion-styled back-and-forth conversation instead of getting a lecture. If you prefer an organized lecture-based course with short answer assignments and clear-cut assessments, this is not the class for you. The professor is not for you, and you should consider how many other required courses and electives you have to take for the BE concentration. Maybe consider switching to EEP or EAM so you have fewer required courses that are not up your alley.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to put certain business tools into practice. I learned how to research and develop a market size using incomplete information. I learned how how VCs work and the type of information they are looking for in a presentation. I also changed how I look at green energy projects and realized they are much more complex than just harnessing a renewable energy source.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I was able to think more critically about business models and to assess the effectiveness for climate and impact-focused businesses in particular for creating the impact they desire while still remaining profitable and able to stay in business. I also learned the challenges of working with a first time founder, and trying to open them up to different ways of thinking, as they can get very bogged down in the details of their organization and double down on current methods of doing things, which might not be the most time or other resource efficient. Lastly, in working with a team and taking on the unofficial role of the project manager, I learned more about how to motivate team members, and where I need to provide a little push where needed vs. when to step back and let other people do the work on their own terms, even if I might do it a bit differently myself.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think that the "lessons" that Michelle and Alexis gave were very high level overviews of some basic concepts taught in business school, but did not go into anywhere near enough detail to be helpful. I think that some more activities around applying these concepts, or more detailed lessons could have been helpful. Alternatively, perhaps a short reading could be provided prior to lessons so that the class could all get to at least a baseline understanding prior to the class discussions. This could be more helpful for people who were less familiar, and could then allow for a richer discussion for people who were already familiar and wanted to try to take their learning and application to the next level.As noted above, I also think it would have been more interesting and helpful to meet the founders at the beginning of the course as well, and give us more context and more to think about/ consider throughout the term, reducing the time of the learning curve, and allowing for more time for critical thinking and analysis.
